'Animals' are multicellular, eukaryotic organisms of the kingdom 'Animalia' or
'Metazoa'. Their body plan eventually becomes fixed as they develop, although
some undergo a process of metamorphosis later on in their life. Most animals are
motile, meaning they can move spontaneously and independently. All animals must
ingest other organisms or their products for sustenance (see Heterotroph).

Most known animal phyla appeared in the fossil record as marine species
during the Cambrian explosion, about 542 million years ago. Animals are
divided into various sub-groups, including birds, mammals, amphibians,
reptiles, fish and insects.
